isis.stitle: DT-466E and 530E Diesel Engine Service (1995 through 1999) - SECTION 6: CONNECTING RODS, PISTONS, RINGS AND SLEEVES - BEARING FITTING PROCEDURE

step1.para: If bearing-to-crankshaft running clearances exceed specifications because of wear on the crankshaft, replace or regrind the crankshaft and install undersize precision type bearing shells.

note.para: DO NOT ATTEMPT TO REDUCE JOURNAL-TO-BEARING RUNNING CLEARANCES BY REWORKING BEARING CAP, BEARINGS OR BOTH. REGRIND OR REPLACE THE CRANKSHAFT ONLY. REFER TO SECTION 7.

caution.para: REWORKING THE BEARING CAP WILL DESTROY THE ENGINEERED FIT OF THE BEARING SHELLS IN THEIR BORES.

step1.para: Tighten the connecting rod bolts alternately and evenly to the special torque value.

note.para: ABOUT BEARING CRUSH AND SPREAD! Bearing shells must fit tightly in the bore. When bearing shells are inserted into the connecting rod and cap, they protrude above the parting line. This protrusion is required to achieve "BEARING CRUSH". Bearing shells are designed with "SPREAD". That is, the width across the open ends are slightly larger than the diameter of the connecting rod bore into which they are assembled, as shown in Figure 6.26. This condition is designed into the bearing shell causing it to spread outward at the parting line when "CRUSH" load is applied by tightening the bolts. Some snap may be lost in normal use but bearing replacement is not required because of a nominal loss of snap.

step1.para:
When the assembly is drawn up tight, the bearing is compressed, assuring a positive contact between the bearing back and the bore as shown in Figure 6.27
.
Fit connecting rod bearings and measure bearing running clearance as follows:

step2.para: With bearing cap removed, wipe oil from the face of the bearing insert and exposed portion of the crankshaft journal.
Place a piece of "Plastigage(r) " across the full width of the bearing about 6 mm (1/4 in.) off center.
Install the cap and tighten bolts evenly and alternately to special torque value.

note.para: DO NOT turn the crankshaft during running clearance check.

step2.para:
Remove main bearing cap. The "Plastigage(r) " material will be found adhering to either the bearing shell or the crankshaft. DO NOT REMOVE "PLASTICGAGE(r) ". Use "Plasticgage(r) " scale to measure widest point of flattened plastic material ( Figure 6.28
). The number within the graduated marks on the scale indicates the clearance in thousandths of an inch or millimeters (See "SPECIFICATIONS").
Remove the test material and the repeat test for each connecting rod bearing.

note.para: With the precision bearings used, no problem should be encountered. If proper clearance is NOT achieved, a problem with the crankshaft may exist which requires regrinding and the use of undersize bearings. (Refer to Section 7 for Crankshaft Rework Information.) Bearing cap torque is very important. Repeat running clearance check procedure before condemning the crankshaft.

step1.para:
Check clearance of connecting rod by placing a feeler gauge between the connecting rod and the crankshaft journal ( Figure 6.29
).
Check connecting rod side clearance using a dial indicator as follows:

step2.para: Place the tip of the dial indicator on the connecting rod cap.
Pry the connecting rod towards the rear of the engine and "zero" the dial indicator.
Pry the connecting rod toward the front of the engine and read the indicator. Refer to "SPECIFICATIONS" and repeat for all connecting rods.

note.para: The connecting rod side clearance must be checked to be certain that the specified clearance exists.

step2.para: Lack of clearance could indicate a damaged rod or a rod bearing out of position. Excessive clearance may require replacement of the rods or crankshaft. Correct as required.
